questions.question: Pre-Leak-Off Test requirements? (SELECT THREE)

options.B: Line up through kill line; pump at SCR
options.C: Raise bit inside shoe to prevent damage

questions.explanation: LOT needs: Clean uniform mud (A), exposed shoe (D), and virgin formation to test (E). Kill line routing is for well control, not LOT. Bit position varies by procedure.

questions.question: What influences Leak-Off Test results? (SELECT TWO)
questions.explanation: LOT measures formation strength against mud pressure. Variable mud densities (C) give inconsistent baseline. Annular hydrostatic (E) is half the equation. Volume and SCR don't affect static LOT.

questions.question: When is Leak-Off Test performed?

options.B: After drilling shoe and 5-15 feet new formation

questions.explanation: LOT tests FORMATION strength, not cement. Must drill into formation (5-15 ft) to expose it, but not so deep that you're past the shoe protection zone.

questions.question: Conditions for accurate formation strength test? (SELECT THREE)

options.A: Good pressure test of surface equipment

questions.explanation: Accurate LOT needs: No surface leaks (A), reliable readings (C), and consistent mud (D). Annular volume is less critical for static test.

questions.question: Inconsistent mud density in wellbore. How to get most accurate LOT?

options.A: Stop after 10 bbls; read DP pressure
options.B: Condition mud until consistent; then test

questions.explanation: Variable density = variable hydrostatic = unreliable LOT. Circulate to condition and homogenize mud first, then test against known uniform column.

questions.question: Definition of MAASP?

options.B: Pressure above hydrostatic likely causing losses at shoe

questions.explanation: MAASP = Maximum Allowable Annular Surface Pressure. It's the maximum SURFACE pressure before shoe fractures—not the shoe pressure itself.

questions.question: Effect of increased mud weight on MAASP?
questions.explanation: Higher MW = higher hydrostatic = less room for surface pressure before reaching fracture gradient. MAASP decreases.

questions.question: When is MAASP most likely to be exceeded? (SELECT THREE)

options.D: Small margin between hydrostatic and fracture pressure
options.E: Large margin between hydrostatic and fracture pressure

questions.explanation: Large influx (B) creates more casing pressure. Small margin (D) means less room. Long open hole (F) means kick gas can be larger before detection. All increase MAASP risk.

questions.question: Factors affecting MAASP? (SELECT THREE)
questions.explanation: MAASP = f(Fracture pressure, shoe TVD, mud weight). Annular volume affects kick severity, not MAASP directly. pH and pump pressure irrelevant.

questions.question: 9 5/8" casing at 8,900 ft TVD, formation strength 6,351 psi, 11 ppg mud. Calculate MAASP.
When must MAASP be recalculated?
questions.explanation: Any MW change affects MAASP directly. MAASP = f(MW). Recalculate immediately after weight up or weight down.
